headline.main: BRITAIN'S CONTROL OF TRADE IN WAR; Order Brought Out of Commercial Anarchy and Monopolies Suppressed. FOOD FAMINE AVERTED Vast Industries and Businesses Taken Over or Completely Controlled by the Government.

docs.snippet: With the completion in the near future of investigations now in progress under the auspices of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce, the work of putting South America on the commercial map, so to speak, for the benefit of American...
docs.lead_paragraph: With the completion in the near future of investigations now in progress under the auspices of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce, the work of putting South America on the commercial map, so to speak, for the benefit of American manufacturers and exporters will have reached an advanced stage.

docs.snippet: It took considerable hardihood for Grant Stewart and Robert Baker to add another war play to an already lengthy list, yet, as you might suspect from its title, they have done just that in "Arms and the Girl," which was shown to New York for the first...
docs.lead_paragraph: It took considerable hardihood for Grant Stewart and Robert Baker to add another war play to an already lengthy list, yet, as you might suspect from its title, they have done just that in "Arms and the Girl," which was shown to New York for the first time last evening. The event is a happy one, for the new piece at the Fulton is light, bright and pleasantly entertaining.
docs.abstract: "Arms and the Girl," by G. Stewart and R. Baker

headline.main: ARMS AND THE GIRL' ANOTHER WAR PLAY; A Light and Amusing Romance Woven Into the Invasion of Belgium. INTRODUCING FAY BAINTER This Charming Newcomer Takes First Honors in a Well-Staged Comedy at the Fulton.

docs.snippet: The steady inflow of gold since the beginning of the European war has in conjunction with the domestic production brought the total stock of gold in the United States from $1,887,270,664 on Aug. 1, 1914, to $2,636,009,564 on Oct. 1, 1916, the gain in...
docs.lead_paragraph: The steady inflow of gold since the beginning of the European war has in conjunction with the domestic production brought the total stock of gold in the United States from $1,887,270,664 on Aug. 1, 1914, to $2,636,009,564 on Oct. 1, 1916, the gain in the amount of gold in the United States in the twenty-six months period having been $748,738,904.
docs.abstract: Foreign Trade Dept. gives analysis of stock of gold in U. S.

headline.main: STOCK OF GOLD HERE NOW $2,676,009,564; The National City Bank Reports a Gain of $748,738,904 Since the War Began. JUNE INCREASE $115,000,000 Amount of Metal in the Country Double That of 1904 and 40% More Than in August, 1914.
